items.title: North Carolina Amazon workers vote against unionizing
items.summary:
- Workers at an Amazon warehouse in Garner, North Carolina voted against unionizing on February 15, 2025.
- Out of 3,276 ballots cast, 25.3% were in favor of unionizing and 74.7% against.
- The results are pending certification by the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB).
- The worker group CAUSE blamed the outcome on alleged illegal intimidation by Amazon.
- Amazon's spokesperson denied any wrongdoing and highlighted the workers' preference for a direct relationship with the company.

items.title: Apple Intelligence could arrive on Vision Pro in April
items.author: Anthony Ha
items.summary:
- Apple is planning to add Apple Intelligence to its Vision Pro headset as soon as April.
- The update will be part of the visionOS 2.4 software and may have a version available for developers soon.
- Initial offerings will not include an upgraded Siri, and existing upgrades to Siri may be delayed due to engineering issues.

items.title: xAI’s “Colossus” supercomputer raises health questions in Memphis
items.summary:
- Elon Musk’s AI startup xAI plans to use 15 gas turbines to power its "Colossus" supercomputer in Memphis from June 2025 to June 2030.
- The turbines emit hazardous air pollutants (HAP) exceeding EPA's regulations, with each turbine producing 11.51 tons per year.
- The turbines have operated since summer 2024 without public notice, and permits for this operation are still pending approval from the health department.

items.title: Perplexity launches its own freemium ‘deep research’ product
items.author: Anthony Ha
items.summary:
- Perplexity has launched a new deep research tool, joining Google and OpenAI in offering advanced AI research capabilities.
- The tool aims to provide in-depth answers with citations for professional use, unlike consumer chatbots.
- Perplexity's Deep Research is available on the web, with plans to expand to Mac, iOS, and Android apps.
- Users can select 'Deep Research' from a menu, generating detailed reports that can be exported as PDFs.
- The tool scored 21.1% on an AI benchmarking test, outperforming competitors but not matching OpenAI's 26.6% score.
- Unlike OpenAI's $200/month service, Perplexity offers a freemium model with limited queries for non-subscribers and unlimited for subscribers.

items.title: OpenAI teases a ‘simplified’ GPT-5 model
items.author: Cody Corrall
items.summary:
- OpenAI canceled the release of its o3 model, opting for a simplified product instead.
- CEO Sam Altman announced GPT-5 will integrate o3 into ChatGPT and its API.
- GPT-4.5 is expected to be released before GPT-5, marking the end of non-chain-of-thought models.

items.title: Marc Andreessen dreams of making a16z a lasting company, beyond partnerships
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- Marc Andreessen discusses the future of his firm, a16z, considering becoming a publicly traded company.
- He expresses no immediate desire to go public but aims to create a lasting investment company rather than a traditional partnership model.
- Andreessen critiques traditional VC partnerships for lacking underlying asset value and dependent on key individuals.
- He cites historical examples like Goldman Sachs and JP Morgan evolving from partnerships to large corporations.
- a16z already resembles an operating company, with significant staff dedicated to marketing and supporting portfolio companies.
- He notes a key challenge in partnerships is interpersonal relationships among partners.

items.title: What is an encryption backdoor?
items.summary:
- The U.K. government is pushing Apple to create a backdoor for accessing encrypted iCloud data.
- The Investigatory Powers Act (IPA) allows the U.K. to demand such access, raising concerns about the implications of weakened encryption.
- Security experts warn that backdoors could be exploited by malicious actors, leading to identity theft and data breaches.
- The concept of a 'NOBUS' backdoor suggests only authorized agents would have access, but this is heavily criticized as a flawed idea.
- Backdoors have historical precedence, with past efforts such as the NSA's Clipper Chip facing backlash and failure due to privacy concerns.

items.title: These Google Photos alternatives offer tons of storage options at a reasonable price
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Google Photos now offers only 15GB of free storage, down from unlimited free storage for images.
- Alternatives to Google Photos include:
  - **[Flickr](https://www.flickr.com/)**: 1,000 photos for free; paid plans start at $10.44/month for unlimited storage.
  - **[Dropbox](https://www.dropbox.com/)**: 5GB free; paid plans start at $9.99/month for 2TB.
  - **[Ente](https://ente.io/)**: 5GB free, focuses on privacy; paid plans start at $2.49/month for 50GB.
  - **[Cryptee](https://crypt.ee/)**: 100MB free; paid plans start at $3.30/month for 10GB, includes document editor features.
  - **[Amazon Photos](https://www.amazon.com/Amazon-Photos/b?ie=UTF8&node=13234696011)**: 5GB free with Prime membership; paid plans start at $1.99/month for 100GB.
  - **[500px](https://500px.com/)**: Allows 21 high-resolution photos per week for free; premium plans start under $50/year.
  - **[Photobucket](https://photobucket.com/)**: No free storage; $5/month for 1TB.

items.title: Uber sues DoorDash, alleging anti-competitive tactics
items.author: Kirsten Korosec, Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Uber has filed a lawsuit against DoorDash in California, claiming anti-competitive practices aimed at restaurant owners.
- DoorDash allegedly coerces restaurants into exclusive agreements for delivery services, threatening penalties or demotion in app visibility.
- Uber claims this situation has led to substantial financial losses and hampered the growth of its service Uber Direct.

items.title: Court filings show Meta paused efforts to license books for AI training
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- New court filings in the case of [Kadrey v. Meta Platforms](https://www.courtlistener.com/docket/67569326/kadrey-v-meta-platforms-inc/?order_by=desc) indicate Meta has paused discussions with book publishers for AI training data licensing.
- Meta's AI partnership lead, Sy Choudhury, reported slow engagement from publishers during outreach efforts, leading to the decision to pause licensing efforts in early April 2023 due to logistical setbacks.
- The plaintiffs, including authors Sarah Silverman and Ta-Nehisi Coates, allege Meta may have used pirated ebooks for AI model training, raising concerns over copyright infringement.

items.title: AI Alexa and AI Siri face bugs and delays
items.summary:
- Amazon and Apple are facing delays in releasing generative AI features for their digital assistants, Alexa and Siri, respectively.
- Amazon has postponed the release of its updated Alexa, initially scheduled for February 26, to March or later.
- Apple's AI enhancements for Siri are experiencing engineering problems, delaying planned features that may now launch in May or later.
- Both companies aim to compete against advanced AI voice assistants from OpenAI and Google but are struggling with their timelines.

items.title: Figure AI is in talks to raise $1.5B at 15x its last valuation
items.summary:
- Figure AI, a Silicon Valley robotics startup, is in talks to raise $1.5 billion at a $39.5 billion valuation.
- This new valuation is 15 times higher than its $2.6 billion valuation following a $675 million Series B last year.
- The funding round is expected to be led by Align Ventures and Parkway Venture Capital.
- Figure specializes in humanoid robots for commercial and residential applications, reflecting growing interest in robotics due to the AI boom.
- The founder, Brett Adcock, indicated the company has potential contracts for up to 100,000 humanoid robots and has already sold some to BMW.

items.title: SailPoint’s dull debut did little to loosen the stuck IPO window, expert says
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- SailPoint’s IPO on Thursday disappointed expectations for a resurgence in tech IPOs.  
- The stock closed below the $23 initial price on its first day but improved to over $24 on Friday.  
- The company raised over $1.3 billion, using it for operations and debt repayment of approximately $1.5 billion.

items.title: OpenAI says its board of directors ‘unanimously’ rejects Elon Musk’s bid
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI’s board unanimously rejected Elon Musk’s $97.4 billion bid to buy the nonprofit governing OpenAI.
- Board chair Bret Taylor described Musk’s offer as an attempt to disrupt competition.
- OpenAI emphasized its mission and the bid was considered not in the best interest of that mission.
- Musk’s bid would have meant a conversion to a for-profit model, which is currently contested in court.
- Musk, a co-founder of OpenAI, is involved in ongoing legal disputes regarding the company’s actions.

items.title: Bluesky gets growth and analytics tools with BlueSkyHunter launch
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- BlueSkyHunter launched as a subscription service providing analytics and management tools for Bluesky users.
- It features an online dashboard for scheduling posts, automating DMs, and tracking various metrics.
- Created by Borut Udovic, the service aims to support creators and businesses on Bluesky's growing network of over 31.5 million users.
- The service offers a free 40-day trial, with a discounted price of $15 per month for early subscribers (regular price $29).

items.title: Global electricity demand expected to grow 4% annually through 2027
items.summary:
- Global electricity demand is projected to increase by 4% annually through 2027, according to the International Energy Agency.
- Meeting this demand will require new generating capacity exceeding the total capacity of Japan each year.
- Emerging and developing economies are expected to account for 85% of the growth, with Chinese industries driving a 6% annual growth rate.
- U.S. growth will be significant but lower than China, equating to the current demand of California.
- Low-carbon sources like renewables and nuclear are expected to meet nearly all of the demand growth.

items.title: How this weekend’s ‘Tesla Takeover’ protests against Elon Musk came together on Bluesky
items.summary:
- A grassroots movement against Elon Musk's actions gains momentum, organizing protests at Tesla dealerships for February 15.
- Initiated by Joan Donovan and Alex Winter on Bluesky, the protests aim to draw attention to government data handling and Musk's perceived lack of transparency.
- 42 protest events have been set up across various U.S. states, with participation from citizens concerned about Musk's influence on technology and governance.

items.title: DeepSeek founder Liang Wenfeng is reportedly set to meet with China’s Xi Jinping
items.summary:
- Chinese AI startup DeepSeek founder Liang Wenfeng to meet with Xi Jinping and other top politicians.
- The summit may signal a renewed supportive stance toward private-sector firms in China.
- Expected to occur as early as next week; Jack Ma also likely to attend.
- DeepSeek, founded in 2023, gained attention for its strong AI model performance against competitors like OpenAI.

items.title: NATO backs its first cohort of European dual-use startups
items.author: Mike Butcher
items.summary:
- NATO launches its first approved cohort of startups under the Defense Innovation Accelerator for the North Atlantic (DIANA) program.
- The initiative, in partnership with the U.K., aims to enhance investment in defense technology, with 10% of VC funding in Europe going to defense-related ventures.
- Five startups were selected from 2,400 applications for a six-month accelerator program: AI Verse, EIFys, Metahelios, RVmagnetics, and Winse Power.
- Startups will work on dual-use technologies that benefit both military and civilian applications, focusing on areas like AI, sensors, and imaging technologies.
- DASA (Defense and Security Accelerator) is leading the U.K. efforts in collaboration with IoT Tribe and Atmos VC among others.

items.title: Elon Musk’s AI company, xAI, said to be in talks to raise $10B
items.summary:
- xAI is reportedly in talks to raise $10 billion, which would value the company at $75 billion.
- The fundraising effort involves existing investors including Sequoia Capital, Andreessen Horowitz, and Valor Equity Partners.
- If successful, the funding round would bring xAI's total raised capital to $22.4 billion.
- xAI is considering purchasing over $5 billion worth of servers from Dell to enhance its AI technology development, particularly for its Grok models.
- The next major version of Grok, Grok 3, is expected to be released in the coming weeks and is said to outperform other chatbots.

items.title: Meta’s next big bet may be humanoid robotics
items.summary:
- Meta is forming a new team within its Reality Labs division to develop humanoid robots for physical tasks.
- The new robotics group will be led by Marc Whitten, former CEO of Cruise, focusing on hardware and AI.
- Meta plans to create a hardware foundation for the robotics market, rather than building a Meta-branded robot initially, and is in talks with companies like Unitree Robotics and Figure AI for collaboration.

items.title: AI and security startups blossom on cloudy days
items.author: Anna Heim
items.summary:
- Startups related to security and sovereignty raised significant funding despite a clouded economic outlook.
- AI startups raised $110 billion in 2024, a 62% increase year-on-year, while overall startup funding declined by 12%.
- European defense and security tech startups raised $5.2 billion in 2024, comprising 10% of all VC funding in the region, at a record high.
- Mistral AI’s assistant Le Chat became the most downloaded iOS app in France during the Paris AI Summit.
- Data acquired SafeBase for $250 million; CyberArk bought Zilla Security for $165 million, with a potential additional $10 million based on milestones.

items.title: Meta confirms ‘Project Waterworth,’ a global subsea cable project spanning 50,000 kilometers
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Meta has announced Project Waterworth, a subsea cable project of 50,000 kilometers, making it the world's longest.
- The network will connect five continents with landing points in the U.S., Brazil, India, South Africa, among others.
- The project will utilize 24 fiber pair cables with innovative routing to enhance deep-water cable placement.
- Geopolitical factors influenced the project, with a U.S.-India joint statement mentioning cooperation in undersea technologies.
- The cable aims to support digital communication, video services, and online transactions, particularly focused on AI growth in India.
- This is Meta's first wholly-owned cable project, adding it to the ranks of other tech giants involved in subsea infrastructure.

items.title: Mastodon is working to add the controversial ‘quote posts’ feature
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Mastodon introduces the controversial quote posts feature similar to Twitter's.
- The feature has divided users due to its potential for online abuse and negativity.
- Some users support quote posts for easier referencing and response.
- Mastodon will allow users to control whether their posts can be quoted, and users will be notified if their posts are quoted.
- The feature aims to address user safety and privacy concerns amid implementation challenges with ActivityPub protocol.
- Development timelines remain unclear, with Mastodon stating it will take more time to develop the feature.

items.title: DeepSeek: Everything you need to know about the AI chatbot app
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- DeepSeek has gained significant popularity as its chatbot app rose to the top of the App Store and Google Play charts.
- Backed by High-Flyer Capital Management, the company focuses on AI tools for trading.
- Key models include DeepSeek Coder, LLM, Chat, DeepSeek-V2, and DeepSeek-V3, noted for cost efficiency and performance.
- The reasoning model R1 claims to perform well against OpenAI's models but is subject to regulatory controls in China.
- Despite success, some companies and governments are blocking or banning DeepSeek due to security concerns.

items.title: Y Combinator startup Firecrawl seeks AI agent for $15K a year
items.summary:
- Firecrawl, a Y Combinator startup, posted a job ad on its job board seeking an AI agent to autonomously research and build apps.
- The salary offered for the position ranges from $10,000 to $15,000, appealing to AI entities without the need for basic human necessities.
- Founders Caleb Peffer and Nicolas Silberstein view the ad as both a PR stunt and an experiment to attract skilled AI engineers.
- The job ad went viral as it is believed to be the first of its kind for AI agents on the YC job board.
- Firecrawl's web crawling bot complies with Robot.txt, addressing controversial aspects of AI web crawling.
- The company received 50 applicants but plans to relaunch the job posting as none met their standards.

items.title: Instagram tests a ‘dislike’ button for comments
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Instagram confirms testing a downvote button for comments to signal dislike or irrelevance.  
- Feature appears on both Feed posts and Reels, no dislike count will be visible to others.  
- Aim is to improve comment quality and create a friendlier environment, currently testing with a small group.

items.title: Apply to Speak at TechCrunch Sessions: AI
items.summary:
- Event: [TechCrunch Sessions: AI](https://techcrunch.com/events/tc-sessions-ai/?utm_source=tc&utm_medium=post&utm_campaign=tcsessionsai&utm_content=post_callforcontent_02142025&promo=post_callforcontent_02142025&display=) on June 5 at UC Berkeley’s Zellerbach Hall.
- Speakers can apply to lead a 50-minute breakout session with a team of up to four presenters.
- Application deadline is March 7; topics will be voted on by the audience to determine session selection.

items.title: Call for Speakers: TechCrunch All Stage 2025
items.summary:
- TechCrunch All Stage 2025 event is on July 17 in Boston.
- Open call for speakers to share insights on scaling startups.
- Applications for speaking close on April 18, 2025.
- Events include breakout sessions and roundtable discussions.
- Participants will gain visibility and networking opportunities.

items.title: Airbnb CEO says it’s still too early for AI trip planning
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Airbnb is planning to introduce AI technology first in its customer support system, not for trip planning.
- This update will roll out later in summer 2025, following a strong Q4 2024 earnings report.
- CEO Brian Chesky believes AI can greatly enhance customer service but feels it is still too early for AI trip planning, comparing it to the early days of the Internet.
- The technology may evolve to become a travel concierge in the future.
- CFO Ellie Mertz indicated that AI could increase operational efficiency, though it is uncertain if headcount will be affected.
- Airbnb reported earnings of $2.48 billion in Q4 2024, surpassing estimates and reflecting a 15% share price increase.

items.title: ICON, a pioneer in 3D home printing, raises $56M led by Norwest, Tiger Global
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- ICON closed $56 million in Series C funding co-led by Norwest Venture Partners and Tiger Global.
- The funding round also included existing backers such as CAZ Investments and Moderne Ventures, with plans for up to $75 million more.
- The company has raised over $500 million in total and previously had a valuation approaching $2 billion in February 2022.
- Former Congressman Will Hurd joined ICON's board of directors.
- ICON, founded in 2017, is known for its 3D-printed homes, including the first permitted 3D-printed house in the U.S.
- The new capital will support the development of their multi-story 3D printer, Phoenix, focused on low-carbon construction materials.
- ICON continues to build homes and has printed nearly 200 structures in the U.S. and Mexico, including homes for disaster relief and affordable housing.
- Recently, ICON laid off 114 employees to realign team priorities, currently employing around 200 people.

items.title: Europe Denies Dropping AI Liability Rules Under Pressure from Trump
items.summary:
- The European Union has denied that it dropped planned tech regulations due to pressure from the Trump administration.
- The AI Liability Directive, aimed at facilitating consumer lawsuits over AI-related harms, was scrapped to focus on enhancing competitiveness and reducing bureaucracy.
- EU's digital chief, Henna Virkkunen, emphasized a need to streamline regulations rather than respond to external political pressure.
- U.S. Vice President JD Vance recently urged European lawmakers to embrace AI opportunities during a speech in Paris.

items.title: Plain pulls in $15M to aggregate B2B customer services chats into one platform
items.author: Mike Butcher
items.summary:
- Plain, a UK-based startup, raises $15 million in Series A funding led by Battery Ventures.
- The platform consolidates communication channels for customer support, streamlining interactions across Slack, Microsoft Teams, and Discord.
- CEO Simon Rohrbach emphasizes that the platform aids internal collaboration among customer success and engineering teams.
- Funding will help establish a new U.S. office in San Francisco.
- Competitors include Thena and Pylon, with significant investments reported in the same sector.

items.title: TikTok is back on the App Store and the Play Store in the U.S.
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Apple and Google restored TikTok in the U.S. after more than 25 days since its removal on January 18 due to national security concerns.
- Other ByteDance apps, including CapCut and Lemon8, were also restored.
- TikTok started restoring services for existing users on January 19, but remained unavailable for new downloads until now.
- President Trump signed an executive order requiring ByteDance to sell TikTok to a U.S. entity within 75 days or face a ban.
- TikTok accounted for 52 million downloads in the U.S. last year, making it the second most downloaded app according to Sensor Tower data.

items.title: Hotstar and JioCinema merge into JioHotstar as Reliance tightens grip on streaming in India
items.author: Manish Singh
items.summary:
- Hotstar and JioCinema have merged into a new platform called JioHotstar.
- The merger integrates JioCinema’s library into Disney’s Hotstar, offering extensive local content and over 100 TV channels.
- JioHotstar aims to attract more than 500 million users, providing content in 19 languages with various subscription plans.
- The merger consolidates major sports rights under one platform, including the Indian Premier League and FIFA World Cup.
- JioCinema's app will be phased out post-transition of existing subscribers to JioHotstar.

items.title: Turo scraps plans for an IPO
items.author: Kirsten Korosec
items.summary:
- Turo has withdrawn its plans for an IPO after a three-year wait, according to a regulatory filing.
- The company publicly filed for an IPO in January 2022 but faced changing market conditions and decelerating growth.
- Turo's decision follows the recent shutdown of peer-to-peer car-sharing company Getaround's U.S. operations.
- As of September 2024, Turo reported 150,000 active hosts globally and $722 million in revenue for the first nine months of 2024, an 8.6% increase from 2023, but down from $879.7 million in 2022.
- The business saw a decline in 2023 but has shown signs of recovery in 2024, though not enough to pursue an IPO.

items.title: UK drops ‘safety’ from its AI body, now called AI Security Institute, inks MOU with Anthropic
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
[The U.K. government renames the AI Safety Institute to the AI Security Institute aiming to enhance its focus on cybersecurity rather than safety risks.]
[The announcement includes a partnership with Anthropic to explore the use of its AI assistant Claude in public services.]
[This shift aligns with the government's goal to boost economic development through technology and AI despite ongoing safety concerns.]

items.title: Meta CTO says staff should quit if they don’t like Meta’s new policies
items.summary:
- Meta CTO Andrew Bosworth stated employees unhappy with new policies are welcome to quit.
- His remarks followed complaints about layoffs and cuts to DEI programs from employees.
- Bosworth emphasized that leaking internal disagreements should lead to considering alternate employment.
- The firm has started layoffs that have been criticized as unfair by staff, who feel demoralized and disrespected.
- Internal discussions reflect significant turmoil as Meta adjusts major policies, including relaxing content moderation standards.

items.title: Google Gemini now brings receipts to your AI chats
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Google’s Gemini AI can now tailor responses based on past conversations.
- Launching the recall feature for English-speaking subscribers of Google One AI Premium at $20/month.
- Users can manage their chat history, including deletion and recall capabilities, addressing privacy concerns.

items.title: Arm is launching its own chip this year with Meta as a customer
items.summary:
- Arm is starting its own chip production in 2025 with Meta as a customer.
- The chips will primarily be CPUs for large data center servers and customizable for various clients.
- The first in-house Arm chip is expected to be unveiled by summer 2025.
- This marks a strategic shift for Arm, which typically licenses its chip designs to other companies like Apple and Nvidia.

items.title: OpenAI removes certain content warnings from ChatGPT
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI has removed warning messages in ChatGPT indicating potential violations of terms of service.
- The change aims to reduce unnecessary denials and enhance user experience, without allowing harmful or false content.
- Users can now engage in broader discussions, including topics previously flagged, such as mental health and erotica.
- This move follows updates to OpenAI's Model Spec, which emphasizes openness on sensitive topics.
- The decision may be influenced by political pressure and claims of censorship against conservative viewpoints.

items.title: Eon Musk’s full offer letter to buy OpenAI reveals five key details
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- A consortium led by Elon Musk’s x.AI offered $97.4 billion to buy OpenAI, dismissed by CEO Sam Altman.
- The offer has a deadline of May 10, 2025, but OpenAI's board has not formally rejected it yet.
- The transaction will be all-cash, with 100% of the purchase price paid in cash, unlike Musk’s previous debt-financed deals.
- Musk's team wants access to OpenAI’s financial records and personnel prior to the purchase.
- Musk may withdraw his bid if OpenAI maintains its non-profit status, which contradicts his ongoing lawsuit claims.

items.title: Tim Cook teases Apple product news for February 19 — likely the iPhone SE
items.summary:
- Apple CEO Tim Cook announced a new product arrival on February 19, likely a fourth-generation iPhone SE.
- The previous iPhone SE was released three years ago at a price of $429, and Apple aims to replace the Touch ID with Face ID.
- The new iPhone SE is expected to use the same chip as the iPhone 16, enabling generative AI capabilities through Apple's intelligence.

items.title: Anthropic’s next major AI model could arrive within weeks
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- AI startup Anthropic is set to release its next major AI model, described as a ‘hybrid’ capable of deep reasoning and fast responses.
- The model will include a ‘sliding scale’ feature for developers to manage costs associated with deeper reasoning tasks.
- Anthropic’s upcoming model is anticipated to outperform OpenAI’s o3-mini-high reasoning model in programming tasks and is effective at analyzing large codebases.
- CEO Dario Amodei expressed a focus on differentiating reasoning models in a recent interview.

items.title: Phase raises $13M to speed up the UX design process with its no-code platform
items.author: Kate Park
items.summary:
- Phase, founded by Nick Budden, has raised $13 million to enhance the no-code design workflow for UI/UX designers.
- The startup's platform allows designers to create interactive prototypes without coding, aiming to replace tools like Figma and Adobe After Effects.
- Phase successfully launched its platform in South Korea, achieving over 10,000 testers shortly after launch, with plans to expand into U.S. and European markets.

items.title: Another robotaxi operation heads to Texas and Archer scores $300M for its defense mission
items.author: Kirsten Korosec, Sean O’Kane, Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Archer Aviation raised $300 million from investors to enhance its hybrid vertical take-off and landing aircraft program in collaboration with Anduril.
- This funding brings 
Archer's total raised to approximately $3.36 billion.
- The article discusses the increasing robotaxi operations in Texas, with companies like Lyft, Waymo, and Tesla planning to launch services in the state in 2025.

items.title: Tofu is building an omni-channel marketing platform for enterprises
items.author: EJ Cho
items.summary:
- Tofu, founded by EJ Cho, is an AI-driven B2B marketing platform designed for enterprises.
- The platform aims to unify various marketing campaigns and integrates with tools like HubSpot and Salesforce.
- Launched in late 2023, Tofu has achieved 12x revenue growth and raised $12 million in Series A funding, attracting customers like DeepScribe and Check Point.
- Tofu's approach focuses on personalization and repurposing content across different channels based on insights gathered from CMOs.
- The company aims to provide a comprehensive solution rather than being a single-use tool, positioning itself effectively in a crowded market.

items.title: OpenAI scrubs diversity commitment web page from its site
items.author: Dominic-Madori Davis
items.summary:
- OpenAI removed its diversity, equity, and inclusion commitment page, redirecting it to a new page emphasizing people with different backgrounds.
- The previous commitment stated a serious and ongoing investment in DEI, captured by [Internet Archive](https://web.archive.org/) and cited by [CNN](https://www.cnn.com/2023/12/15/tech/openai-board-diversity/index.html).
- The change likely took place between January 22 and January 27, 2025, coinciding with a trend among tech companies distancing from DEI language due to political backlash.
- OpenAI has not commented on whether internal processes have changed following this removal, while still maintaining a page on [fairness](https://openai.com/index/evaluating-fairness-in-chatgpt/) in its model training.

items.title: Seagate acquires Intevac, which makes equipment for hard disk drives, for $119M
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Seagate announced its intent to acquire Intevac for $119 million in an all-cash deal.
- The agreement includes a tender offer of $4 per share for at least 50% of Intevac’s shares, followed by a merger for the remaining shares.
- The acquisition is expected to close in late March or early April 2025, pending customary conditions.
- Intevac, founded in 1991, specializes in thin film deposition systems and has a market cap of around $91.17 million.
- The move aligns with Seagate's strategy in the storage market, particularly with HAMR technology for hard drives.
- This is Seagate's first major acquisition since 2017, bringing its total to 11 acquisitions.

items.title: A comprehensive list of 2024 and 2025 tech layoffs
items.summary:
- In 2024, over 150,000 job cuts across 542 tech companies occurred.
- Companies like [Tesla](https://techcrunch.com/2024/04/15/tesla-layoffs-workers-sales-cybertruck-cuts/), [Amazon](https://techcrunch.com/2024/01/10/amazon-prime-video-and-mgm-studios-laid-off-hundreds-of-employees/), [Google](https://techcrunch.com/2024/01/10/google-cuts-hundreds-of-jobs-in-its-voice-assistance-hardware-teams-as-fitbit-founders-leave/), and [Microsoft](https://techcrunch.com/2024/01/25/microsoft-lays-off-1900-employees-in-activision-blizzard-and-xbox-divisions/) were among those making sizable layoffs.
- A comprehensive layoff tracking for 2024 and 2025 will be updated regularly, with the first significant cuts reported in January 2025.
